courseDescription: The course introduces students to spatial visualization/thinking. The objective of the course is to enhance students' ability of thinking in three dimensions. The course covers student experience with spatial visualization/thinking, design and representation, and strategic use. Educational interventions and testing to improve three-dimensional visualization skills are used. The course does not count towards College of Engineering & Technology graduation credit.
A one-semester course covering topics in civil, environmental, mechanical, electrical and computer engineering.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying mathematical concepts to engineering scenarios

courseDescription: This course introduces engineering and engineering technology disciplines, and develops problem-solving and teamwork skills required in the design and commissioning of an engineered product.  Students will collaborate in hands-on, group projects to understand the engineering design process and explore roles and responsibilities in an engineering team. Students will develop technical skills, such as identifying, formulating, and solving engineering problems, prototype creation and testing, representation and analysis of data using software packages to form conclusions and solve problems. Students will also learn professional skills needed to become successful engineering students and engineers including, but not limited to teamwork, project management, communication (written, oral, and graphical), engineering ethics, information literacy, and critical reading skills.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Forming conclusions based on data analysis
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Roles and responsibilities in an engineering team
Professional skills for engineering students and engineers

courseDescription: Introduction to engineering problem-solving through computer programming. Topics include computational thinking, program design, algorithm development, and testing. Programming language concepts will include variables, data types and expressions, assignment, control-flow statements, and functions. Laboratory exercises involve C++ and Matlab to solve engineering problems (information processing, simulation, data analysis).
Interdisciplinary or multidisciplinary topics for first year students enrolled in engineering or engineering technology majors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team collaboration in diverse fields
Presentation of complex engineering concepts to non-engineers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integration of knowledge from different engineering disciplines
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in a multidisciplinary environment

courseDescription: Interdisciplinary or multidisciplinary topics for second year students enrolled in engineering or engineering technology majors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team communication in engineering projects

courseDescription: A study of the theory and best practices involved in conducting physically-dispersed engineering team collaboration.  Student teams will apply e-Engineering concepts using a distributed product engineering scenario.  Course module topics include project management, virtual teaming, distributed collaborative tools, and scenario-specific engineering skills.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of distributed engineering scenarios

courseDescription: This course prepares the engineering and engineering technology students for the Fundamentals of Engineering Examination.

courseTitle: Introduction to Engineering Design for Teachers
courseDescription: This course is for K-12 teachers seeking endorsement. No credit will be given to students pursuing majors in the College of Engineering and Technology. The major focus of this course is to expose students to the design process, research and analysis, teamwork, communication methods, global and human impacts, engineering standards, and technical documentation. Topics include engineering design process, modeling, sketching, measurement, statistics and applied geometry, engineering drawing standards, CAD solid modeling, reverse engineering, consumer product design innovation, graphic design and virtual design teams.

This course is for K-12 teachers seeking endorsement. No credit will be given to students pursuing majors in the College of Engineering and Technology. Scalar methods and free body diagrams are employed in the analysis of discrete and distributed force systems and their application to bodies in external equilibrium. Friction, moment of inertia, and center of gravity are also included.

This course is for K-12 teachers seeking endorsement. No credit will be given to students pursuing majors in the College of Engineering and Technology. The basic laws of thermodynamics, properties of fluids, heat and work and their applications in processes and cycles, and an introduction to conduction heat transfer will be covered.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to apply heat and work concepts in processes and cycles

courseTitle: Veterans in Engineering and Engineering Technology Seminar
courseDescription: This course aims to augment the transition from service to student to engineer through helping the veteran achieve a sense of belonging to the engineering profession through class discussions, seminars, and workshops designed to develop their identities as engineers and increase their feeling of belonging in engineering fields through self-efficacy and help with their persistence to degree completion. Class activities are designed to build a sense of community and increase students' relevance by helping students develop a career identity in engineering.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective team communication in engineering projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting technical issues in engineering projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading engineering teams towards project goals

courseDescription: This course introduces Small Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (sUAS) types and platforms (such as multirotor, fixed wing, hybrids) and explores mission planning, applications, payloads, flight authorization processes, and crew resource management. Additionally, this course introduces operation of autonomous vehicles in the National Airspace System including Universal Traffic Management, radio frequency allocations, and airport usage, including knowledge of government and industry compliance standards. Attention will be paid to topics of system integration for operations efficiency, risk management, safety, and human factors and human / machine interface in autonomous systems. Includes case studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding Small Uncrewed Aircraft Systems (sUAS) types and platforms
Knowledge of Universal Traffic Management for autonomous vehicles
Radio frequency allocations for autonomous vehicles
Understanding airport usage for autonomous vehicles
Compliance standards in government and industry for autonomous vehicles
System integration for operational efficiency in autonomous systems
Knowledge of safety protocols for autonomous systems
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective crew resource management for sUAS operations
Communication skills for operating autonomous vehicles in National Airspace System
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and managing human factors in autonomous systems
Analyzing human-machine interface in autonomous systems
Critical evaluation of system integration for operations efficiency
Risk assessment and mitigation in autonomous systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Efficient crew coordination for autonomous vehicle missions
Adherence to compliance standards for government and industry regulations

courseDescription: A look at engineering multi-rotor Uncrewed Aerial System (UAS) design. Course topics will include Stability and control of UAS, Electric propulsion and battery technology. Overview of sensors (lidar, sonar, vision etc.); autopilot design and automatic control; airframe structural design of UAS; Flight dynamics and simulation for UAS. Accompanying laboratory topics include motor/propeller testing, building small quadcopters, understanding system elements, PID tuning, programming UAS, and autonomous drone operations. Students will learn to specify all components including motors, propellers, power system, autopilot, GPS, power monitor, frame, etc.  Additional topics will include autopilot setup, firmware configuration, telemetry configuration, ground station setup and sensor specifications and integration (lidar, sonar, radar, optical flow). Mission planning, and test flights will complete the course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Flight dynamics and simulation for UAS
Specifying components (motors, propellers, power system, autopilot, GPS, etc.)
Sensor specifications and integration (lidar, sonar, radar, optical flow)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating on drone design and construction projects
Communicating technical information effectively to team members
Coordinating mission planning and test flights with team members
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing data from sensors for flight optimization
Optimizing PID tuning for flight stability
Designing solutions for autonomous drone operations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading drone design and construction projects
Providing guidance and direction to team members

courseTitle: Fixed Wing and VTOL UAS Design and Construction
courseDescription: This course covers fixed wing aerodynamics and aircraft performance, propeller performance; basic stability and automatic control of aircraft. Introduction to vertical takeoff and landing, hybrid UAS design including tail sitting and lift-to-cruise configurations. Electric propulsion: motor selection, prop matching and system integration. Basic airframe structural design methods. Instrumentation for autonomous flight. Accompanying laboratory topics include: building small fixed wing/VTOL aircraft; autopilot configuration; flight test, planning and operations.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in flight test operations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of aircraft performance data
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading small fixed wing/VTOL aircraft construction teams

courseDescription: This interdisciplinary class is a mission based, collaborative course with majors across the college working alongside industry partners and or mentors. Students will work in teams to research, design, build (or rebuild existing) Unmanned Vehicles and apply them toward ecologically, humanitarian or 'customer based' focused projects.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with industry partners and mentors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical thinking in design and implementation

courseTitle: Multidisciplinary Topics in Engineering and Technology
courseDescription: Special interdisciplinary or multidisciplinary topics of interest with emphasis on emerging areas in engineering.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Team collaboration in diverse areas of engineering
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Integration of multiple engineering disciplines for problem-solving

courseDescription: An introduction to foundations of design and civil, environmental, electrical, mechanical, and computer engineering.  The course will consist of secondary school appropriate content and concepts that directly correlate with the state and local school systems' science and mathematics curriculum.  May lead to a Project Lead the Way certification when applicable.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effectively explaining engineering concepts to secondary school students
Collaborating with other teachers to integrate engineering into science and math curriculum
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Applying engineering problem-solving methods to real-world scenarios
Analyzing and evaluating engineering solutions for different problems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading engineering projects in a secondary school setting
Organizing and managing engineering-related activities for students

courseDescription: An introductory seminar on specific multi-disciplinary or interdisciplinary engineering topics for MS or HS teachers.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with other teachers on engineering projects
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading engineering projects in a classroom setting
Organizing engineering seminar materials for teaching purposes

courseDescription: Financial engineering management, accounting, financial reports and analysis, capital budgeting, investment decisions.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaboration with cross-functional teams on financial projects

courseDescription: Introduction to fundamental concepts in the analysis of organizations.  Examination of social, structural, procedural, and environmental aspects by systems approach.  Modules include:  History and systems of organizations and management; Basic organizational systems and models; Organizational behavior models; Integration of systems perspectives; and Organizational structures.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of organizational analysis findings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of structural inefficiencies in organizations

courseDescription: This course is designed to provide engineers and engineering technologists with the knowledge, skills and experience needed to create products and services that will be attractive to consumer markets and to bring those products and services to market in new commercial ventures.  Topics covered include: how to evaluate entrepreneurial opportunities in the engineering field; elements of a viable business plan; governance models; management succession planning; use of social media; and creating an ethical engineering enterprise in the global economy.

This course is designed to provide engineers and engineering technologists with the knowledge, skills and experience needed to create products and services that will be attractive to consumer markets and to bring those products and services to market in new commercial ventures. Topics covered include: How to evaluate entrepreneurial opportunities in the engineering field; elements of a viable business plan; governance models; management succession planning; use of social media; and creating an ethical engineering enterprise in the global economy.

courseTitle: Leadership and Human Dynamics for the Entrepreneurial Engineer
courseDescription: This course covers the concepts, skills, and characteristics of effective and successful entrepreneurial leaders in the 21st century. The course covers leadership for entrepreneurial engineers through case studies and literature review in areas such as the fundamentals of leadership, ethical leadership, social capital, emotional intelligence, and three-dimensional leadership.

This course is the capstone of the Entrepreneurship and Innovation graduate certificate for engineers. With data and expertise through prior certificate coursework, students develop and present a comprehensive and viable entrepreneurial business plan in engineering. Topics covered include: Product lifecycle management, marketing and strategic planning, entrepreneurial finance, and effective presentation techniques. The final presentation is delivered to a panel of ODU faculty and engineering practitioners who provide sound feedback to the student.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Receiving and implementing feedback from panel members
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Developing strategic plans for business growth

courseDescription: A one-semester course covering advanced topics in bioelectrics.  The course will cover advanced application of pulsed power and plasma in the medical, biological and environmental fields. (Cross-listed with ECE 630).
Technical and Digital Skills: Plasma technology in medical, biological, and environmental fields

courseDescription: Nuclear power and nuclear energy; solar energy; wind energy; geothermal energy; hydroelectric power; hydrogen as energy resource; hydrogen fuel cells; hybrid technologies; global economics and environmental impacts of carbon-free energy.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with team members on energy projects
Collaboration with stakeholders for project implementation
Presenting carbon-free energy proposals to decision-makers
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Troubleshooting issues in renewable energy systems
Analyzing environmental impacts of different energy sources
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management for carbon-free energy initiatives
Leading a team in the implementation of clean energy projects
Strategic planning for transitioning to carbon-free energy sources

courseDescription: System management principles; energy systems safety and security; automation and control; environmental effects and comparative risk assessment; energy storage; carbon sequestration; energy systems scale up issues; energy systems integration; hybrid systems; energy systems optimization; effects of public policies on energy systems management.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of energy system concepts
Collaboration on energy systems integration projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparative risk assessment in energy systems
Critical evaluation of energy system scale-up issues
Identifying optimization opportunities in energy systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in implementing public policies affecting energy systems management

courseDescription: Special interdisciplinary or multidisciplinary topics of interest with emphasis on emerging areas in engineering.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting complex engineering concepts to non-technical audiences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Innovative solutions to complex engineering challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Strategic project planning in engineering contexts

courseDescription: Individual analytical, experimental, computational and/or design study selected by the student and supervised by the course instructor.
Technical and Digital Skills: Design study in renewable energy technologies
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presenting research findings in energy engineering
Collaborating with peers on energy-related projects
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing experimental results in energy systems
Identifying solutions to energy efficiency challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing independent energy projects
Leading a research study in energy engineering
Managing time effectively for energy analysis tasks

courseDescription: Critical evaluation of published literature; experimental design and analysis; optimization methods; pre-project planning; definition of scope, projects risks, technical, economical, social, and political constraints; execution strategies; effective proposal development.
Effective communication techniques, strategic planning, building collaborative relationships, conflict management, building high-performance teams, risk management, managing innovations.

Scope of engineering ethics, moral reasoning and ethical theories, the engineer's responsibility for safety, responsibilities to the employer, responsibilities to the public, rights of engineers, global issues, professional codes of ethics, case studies.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of professional codes of ethics in engineering
Knowledge of global ethical issues in engineering
Familiarity with ethical theories in engineering ethics
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of ethical responsibilities to employers and the public
Respectful engagement in discussions on engineering ethics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of ethical considerations in engineering decisions
Analyzing case studies to identify ethical implications
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading ethical discussions within engineering teams
Taking responsibility for safety in engineering projects
Demonstrating ethical leadership in engineering practices

courseDescription: This course is a pass/fail course for master's students in their final semester. It may be taken to fulfill the registration requirement necessary for graduation.  All master's students are required to be registered for at least one graduate credit hour in the semester of their graduation.
